manifests/init.pp.message:
Because this is specific to wsgi then I think it's better to have an independent keystone::wsgi::uwsgi class to define all parameters for uwsgi. This helps us implement additional parameters like ports etc later.

Also, because the way we setup wsgi is supposed to be same in the all services. Thus it would make more sense to implement the basic implementation in puppet-openstacklib and use that class.

If you want to make this happen during configuration phase and trigger restart of services then you should add something like the following example into deps.

```
  Anchor['keystone::config::begin']
  -> Keystone_uwsgi_config<||>
  ~> Anchor['keystone::config::end']
```

Note that if you implement the base class in puppet-openstacklib as I suggested in my earlier comment then you can implement the dependency like

```
  Anchor['keystone::config::begin']
  -> Openstacklib::Wsgi::Uwsgi<||>
  ~> Anchor['keystone::config::end']
```

manifests/wsgi/uwsgi.pp.message: As I mentioned in my previous comment I think we should implement the base class in openstacklib and use that class from this class, because we are supposed to require the same set of parameters for all services.
You don't need to use undef but set the default value.
Is there any specific reason why you don't use $::os_workers ?

As I mentioned earlier because we expect similar configurations required in each services, it would be better to implement a base class in openstacklib.
It might looks overkilling at this point but definitely helps us when we need any common logic later.

I have submitted a change to puppet-openstacklib [1] which implements the basic resource type.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/+/781230

What we need is to split this change to two parts and set dependencies like;

 1. puppet-keystone: Introcude keystone_uwsgi_config into puppet-keystone
 2. puppet-openstacklib: add openstacklib::wsgi::uwsgi
 3. puppet-keystone: Add keystone::wsgi::uwsgi using openstacklib::wsgi::uwsgi

Another option would be to keep the current implementation and submit another commit to replace current implementation by openstacklib::wsgi::uwsgi
I'll take the road of "another option" and will openstacklib in a 2nd commit instead of calling keystone_uwsgi_config directly.

This is not consistent with expectation from unit tests. I have spitted my patch to puppet-openstacklib so you can use that implementation in openstacklib by depending on the first patch.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/+/781230

spec/classes/keystone_wsgi_uwsgi_spec.rb.message:
Do we need this ? My concern is that we are likely to drop support for service_name=>'keystone' in CentOS/Ubuntu because they no longer provides standalone service, so we should remove this if this is not required.

Another option would be to implement a logic in the bottom block to run keystone::wsgi::uwsgi tests only for Debian.
Is it intentional that these examples are not tested ?

doc/source/reference/logging-and-monitor.message:
I would rather add a note in ReST syntax, so it's more visible:

.. note::
   text

I tend to think that those ReST note blocks get a bit overused, and once there are too many of them you stop reading them. I don't care enough to fight about it though :)

This does raise a good point though that maybe this information is too important to tack on the end of a sentence in parentheses. It also affects you if you're not building images, since you still need to know which ones to override the install_type for when deploying with a default of binary. I guess it just needs a little extra on L41.

This looks like an unofficial link shortener.  Fine for IRC convs, etc, but not for a commit message that might live a lot longer than this site does.  Please could we use the full BUG url.

barbican_tempest_plugin/tests/rbac/v1/te.message: Do we need to validate the return?  confirm that the returned data matches the order_ref?
I was mainly interested in not getting a Forbidden reply, but we can certainly check the response data.

Similar comment here as the container review. What happens if two classes (ProjectMemberTests and ProjectAdminTests) attempt to run this at the same time?

I'm curious if we won't see transient timing issues because of a 409 Conflict down the road.
Barbican doesn't enforce unique name constraints.  I think there's an argument to be made that we probably should, but that's a topic for another day. 😊

Is a use in one project allowed to view orders for another? I assume orders are scoped to projects (at least based on the last time we talked about this?)

If so, do we want to add a case here where we create an order owned by a separate project and then make sure the project-member here can't GET it?
Yep, all negative test are going to be in follow-up patches.  Trying to keep these small-ish for easier reviews.
A project-reader should able to get order in their project, right? Or are we disallowing that for project-readers because orders are sensitive?
I think we decided to not let readers read. 😜  Going with very few permissions for reader, which does not include orders.
We could add another assertion here that project-readers can't create orders for other project, too.
Ack, yeah, will do negative tests with all three personas.

tests/templates/globals-default.j2.message: Need to add quay mirror here.

Nope, it's irrelevant. We use the mirror directly. This only substitutes DockerHub url when you are not explicit in the image identifier. In fact, we could drop this at all if not for building the images from time to time (as we fetch bases from there).

now there is no way to turn off --exit-on-validation-errors because it is always true, whether specified or not.

If we're going to fix this issue here, --exit-on-validation-errors would need to be deprecated and a new option like --warn-on-validation-errors would be needed.

As an alternative to this change, how about all callers to os-net-config in tripleo-heat-templates have --exit-on-validation-errors added to the arguments?

uh, right, it should just be commented out

healthcheck/common.sh.message: Why don't we just use ss to look for the port rather than lsof

actually, this is great idea. Now, once we have that wrapper func that uses grep for advanced filtering, we could as well switch to ss. Before that I think that was not possible since ss provides less flexibility compared to lsof ports/pids built-in filters?

I found some subtle differences, like missing PID info, see:

$ ss -untap
udp         UNCONN           0             0                            0.0.0.0:111                         0.0.0.0:*
$ sudo lsof -n -w -P -a -iUDP
rpcbind     971            root    6u  IPv4   22412      0t0  UDP *:111

so the former cannot be grepp'ed by pids, only by ports...
if you don't mind we can redesign to ss after we are sure this cache based approach works
so even though ss is like twice faster on a 1000 iterations (holser has tested that), it shows less information, so we cannot use it, at least for UDP

It's still potential race here as there is a chance that all containers will get age expired and start doing lsof -n -w -P -a -iTCP -iUDP.

It should be mutex here.

no, there is no races nor deadlocks. No mutexes/locks please. I made it lockless intentionally. If it expires, the first who creates (or sees the created) snapshot, will start using it. If multiple created (like when a 2nd container started writing it before the 1st one has finished writing another one), that's totally fine. The topmost file (from ls -t) will be picked up for other containers use.

pipes are evil. You can do one awk

awk '!/(LISTEN)/ "\b($pids)\b.*\b($ports)\b"

it works since there is always LISTEN ports on a Linux system, so the first grep never fails. And if it does, misbehaving healthchecks are the least problem for such a system where nothing listens any ports.

you can simplify that as
age=$(($(date +'%s') - $(date +'%s' -r bindep.txt)))

wondering if we couldn't make a 2-steps here instead:
- first with ss
- if we don't find with ss, fallback on lsof

The goal here is to get a faster process - ss SHOULD answer most of the cases... ? Though it doesn't have the same output, of course :/.

Another idea: instead of running those commands, we can go check in /proc/<PID>/net and parse the content in there? IIRC the format of, say, /proc/<PID>/tcp is known and we might be able to extract the needed data?
I don't think traversing /proc will be faster than ss.

I'd rather avoid adding this caching thing - it's adding complication to the healthcheck, and... well. I'm not that sure it's a real improvement - maybe on the perf side, but that's pretty much all. I'd rather try to rely on no cache, and no lsof.

I'm working my way in parsing /proc/PID/net/tcp - it's not that complicated, and apparently an awk one-liner seem to do it (just having a difficulty with hex 2 dec conversion), but that should do it.

ss doesn't provide the needed things, unfortunately. For the records, I made the move to lsof in order to simplify the whole thing about a year ago - it allowed to drop a ton of pipes and other things we had to call in order to get the whole status.

Here, I'm not talking about "traversing /proc", no. I'm talking about targeting specific files and directories. A PoC is available here btw:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/785004
I think that would make the code overcomplicated and hard to support... Why do we care about performance of the cached view at all?
the latter approach looks feasible as an alternative to lsof and caching approaches tho

swift/cli/relinker.py.message:
Should probably be more like a

 logger.info(msg)
device_list should be made into a set at some point if it isn't already - the listdir will have devices but the list from command line might not
Done
worth checking sig == 0?

Yeah, signal handling of the children is definitely under-tested (even just manually). If it's *not* 0, we should treat it as an error, since we have to assume the child didn't finish processing.

Also need to look at signal handling of the parent, e.g. to make sure that sending a TERM fans out to the children.
no summary log for ok completion?

Each worker is already going to log something like

 N hash dirs processed (cleanup=T/F) (P files, Q linked, R removed, S errors

I mainly wanted to make sure that error & warning summaries showed up somewhere obvious and not lost in the middle -- IDK that I care about "normal" exits.

IDK that this is worth logging; all the workers should complain the same way, and do so quickly:

 [pid=71086, devs=sdb1] No policy found to increase the partition power.
 [pid=71084, devs=sdb5] No policy found to increase the partition power.
if status not in 0,1,2 should we just set final_status=1? the unexpected status is logged
Done
a timestamp might be useful (elapsed time?) - if only to reinforce that this message is not 'real-time' logging of the completion
Done
ok, so we do see a log as each worker completes, as well as this summary when all have completed

currently the final_messages only relate to abnormal exist codes, but they are logged at info, which made me notice that the Relinker.run() also logs its final status at info regardless of the error code (although warnings are logged at warning level along the way) - should we make the Relinker final log message level warning if there have been errors, and similarly should this be a warning level log here?
Done

I'd be ok with this dest being renamed to device_list (or devices and the devices dest being renamed to device_path). Obviously the options need to remain as they are, although --devices is now a bit unfortunate.
Yeah, I always thought https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.27.0/etc/object-server.conf-sample#L9 was unfortunate...
off-topic: wonder if a --cleanup option would be appropriate, and deprecate the actions?
Done

We're calling fork more times than we should:

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/test/unit/common/test_utils.py#L7727

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/obj/replicator.py#L272

Apr  2 21:54:11 saio object-6010: [pid=89322, devs=sdb1] 0 hash dirs processed (cleanup=False) (0 files, 0 linked, 0 removed, 0 errors)
Apr  2 21:54:11 saio object-6010: [pid=89324, devs=] 0 hash dirs processed (cleanup=False) (0 files, 0 linked, 0 removed, 0 errors)
precedence seems to work for me

manifests/profile/base/glance/backend/ci.message: What is this "None" default hiera value? It's not a valid concept in cinder's world, so perhaps it has specific significance to glance? If it's a valid value for glance then I think it needs to be quoted so it's a string. Your unit test doesn't pick this up because it overrides the value with a valid string.

I still don't believe 'None' (a string) is correct. Glance has a 'None' default value, and puppet-glance [1] correctly defaults to $::os_service_default. I think you want the default hiera value here to be 'undef' just like the other parameters (e.g. L99). So, unless the input value is overridden, this will result in 'undef' being passed in on L124, which will cause puppet-glance to use its own default value (which is $::os_service_default), which in turn will cause glance to use its default value, which is None.

[1] If0e3e0bd01f976e5a32aa9355ac5dd99425722a3

BTW, should this patch Depends-On [1]?

Yes, you are absolutely right, but the pick() function I'm using at L110 would fail if i keep default hiera value 'undef', since the function requires at least one non empty value.

ATM, using pick() is the only solution I can think of if we are having the GlanceCinderVolumeType in multistore_config{}.

About Depends-On - Yes, it was, but since it's merged I removed it from commit msg.

To avoid the issue with hiera/pick, you can implement if-else logic instead to set _real parameters. I think we didn't notice the issue when we implemented the logic for description because tripleo set the parameter at that time but might need the same for it.

(This is off-topic)
Precisely speaking "undef" is not replaced by the default in puppet-glance but used as a valid parameter input. These values are passed to *_config but treated like $::os_service_default because of current implementation in the openstack_config provider.

https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/puppet/provider/openstack_config/ini_setting.rb#L15-L17
https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/puppet/provider/openstack_config/ruby.rb#L43-L45

Consider using puppet's pick_default() function, which supports an 'undef' default value. See [1] for an example.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/src/branch/master/manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume/dellsc.pp#L43

This logic suggests configuring volume type in a multistore_config backend requires you also configure it in the primary backend. In other words, if $cinder_volume_type is 'undef' then GlanceCinderVolumeType entries in the multistore_config are ignored.

Is that the intention?

For single cinder store, $cinder_volume_type will be 'undef' & there would be no GlanceCinderVolumeType entries in multistore_config because volume_type is not required to be set for single cinder store.

In heterogeneous multiple backends as well, if there is single 'cinder' store then also there would not be GlanceCinderVolumeType entry in multistore_config 

So, basically if GlanceCinderVolumeType is available in multistore_config then $cinder_volume_type will never be 'undef' and $cinder_volume_type = undef means there would be no GlanceCinderVolumeType entries in multistore_config.

> For single cinder store, $cinder_volume_type will be 'undef' & there would be no GlanceCinderVolumeType entries in multistore_config because volume_type is not required to be set for single cinder store.

While you don't need to specify a volume type when there is only one cinder store, I can quite easily imagine a scenario where a where it would be useful to do so. Specifying a volume type could be useful in order to store volumes and cinder-backed glance images in separate locations. This could help prevent quota issues, where user volumes and glance images are competing for space.

> In heterogeneous multiple backends as well, if there is single 'cinder' store then also there would not be GlanceCinderVolumeType entry in multistore_config 

See my previous comment

> 
> So, basically if GlanceCinderVolumeType is available in multistore_config then $cinder_volume_type will never be 'undef' and $cinder_volume_type = undef means there would be no GlanceCinderVolumeType entries in multistore_config.

Right, which is why I questioned "and $cinder_volume_type != undef" portion in L116. Would this be an effective replacement for L116..L120:

  $cinder_volume_type_real = pick_default($backend_config['GlanceCinderVolumeType'], $cinder_volume_type, undef)

spec/classes/tripleo_profile_base_glance.message: I recall a previous discussion, and am not sure if you really want to be setting this to a string 'None'. If L52 were deleted then the param would default to undef, which I believe is what you're testing with this test case, yes?
The "=>" are aren't aligned with lines above.
This doesn't look right. It suggests glance will look for a cinder volume type named "None"

common/deploy-steps.j2.message: Let's call this post_host_prep_tasks or pre_deploy_step_tasks.  I think the latter might be preferred.

IIUC the intent here is to be able to hook tasks that run after overcloud common bootstrap tasks. I am not totally convinced on the naming of this playbook, though I don't have a strong objection to it being name as proposed either.

Today, common bootstrap tasks are mostly container related but are not limited to. There is also a somewhat convention that post_* task playbooks are named after certain playbooks (e.g. post_deploy_steps, post_update_steps_tasks, external_post_deploy_steps_tasks, etc).

An alternative name could be post_overcloud_common_bootstrap_tasks which is, admittedly, mouthful. I'm fine with it as is, just wanted to raise this for awareness and potential discussion should there be a need to.

This is the equivalent of the "Overcloud common bootstrap tasks playbook being proposed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781963. Should post_container_setup_tasks.yaml be added after this task?
I probably want to use a block here, although in the previous patchset when I was using a block I was hitting some rather odd ansible behaviour (i.e. some nodes would just get skipped)
Don't put this in the loop. This should just be --start-at-task 'Pre Deployment Steps Tasks'.  We want be able to start at this overall stop but not at a specific role's
This should have when condition for - tripleo_role_name == '{{role.name}}' otherwise this could run on all nodes
Thanks :) We literally saw that just now and were testing the change
I think we can use list_concat_unique instead of yaql here (intention is to use less of yaql)? I've converted others with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/784729

I've changed the existing ones assuming we'll change this one before adding:) But if it's merged as is then I'll update that patch.

We should not add yaql when not necessary as it's memory intensive and we're working on reducing the usage of yaql functions.

Cool! :)
Rabi, maybe you could rebase yours on top of this one (close to being approved) and transform it to list_concat_unique?

tripleoclient/v1/tripleo_deploy.py.message: does this work if redis and ovn are actually deployed? I'm not sure they are in the CI coverage on this patch. Don't you need a use_neutron:False here?

I don't think we should attempt to connect to Keystone or Neutron for the standalone install.

Worse case scenario, we end up talking to Keystone of the standalone environment we already have deployed.

The ansible module will try to connect to neutron, when the endpoint isn't there it falls back to validates that an IP address was provided in FixedIPs and uses that if that is the case.
This patch is required for tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario001-standalone to pass on [1], see log [2] on that patch.



[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/777259 
[2] https://d08e901b1365b4f966ba-c2c178731190b96d718ae1e4710dfab3.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/777259/8/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario001-standalone/3820fb1/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/standalone-ansible-u54wx6gd/service_vip_vars.yaml

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3api.py.message:
I thought we let ops define their own prefix. Does this overwrite what they may have already defined. Although maybe we're defining our own logger so maybe it's ok?

I must admit it's been a while since I've played with the statsd swift subsystem.

So, near as I can tell, we've got prefixes and we've got prefixes ;-)

When we set up the logger [0], we set a base_prefix that can be operator defined. But there's also a *tail_prefix* that defaults to the logger's name; that's the part we update here.

I'll admit, the whole thing feels weird. However, without it, I'd *sometimes* get stats like

  proxy-server.s3api.400.AuthorizationHeaderMalformed

and *sometimes* like

 proxy-server.account.s3api.400.AuthorizationHeaderMalformed

... and that's not great :-/

FWIW, we do something just like this in proxy/server.py [1]. I suspect that's what's causing the spotty results above, though I'm not clear on why s3api and the proxy-server are using the same logger/statsd client...

[0] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/common/utils.py#L2394
[1] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/proxy/server.py#L505

playbooks/common-tasks/dynamic-address-f.message:
ansible_facts[ hostvars[inventory_hostname] | json_query(find_bridge) | replace('-', '_') ].ipv4.address or really
ansible_facts[ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['container_networks'][network_address]['bridge'] | replace('-', '_'') ]['ipv4']['address']

What is the cost of a json_query?

This whole playbook seems silly.

duplicate ' ?

If you want to change this and remove json_query perhaps that should be a separate patch as I think there is a risk of breaking existing behaviour here.

So what are we ending up with here? (assuming 'network_address: container_address')

{{ hostvars[inventory_hostname] | json_query(find_bridge) | replace('-','_') }} resolves down to br_mgmt

So now your metal_query becomes

hostvars[inventory_hostname] | json_query("\"ansible_facts[br_mgmt]\".ipv4.address")

If anything the metal_query should end up as "ansible_facts.br_mgmt.ipv4.address"
I think these need to go.

Thats not using a facts var to return the bridge name, it's defaulting the value to a string like "ansible_br_mgmt"

It's quite easy to copy this task out into a test.yml and poke at the behaviour for real tbh - I can't say without trying it if any adjustments to this will work or not.

playbooks/molecule/pre.yml.message: hm... do we *really* want to enable it? tripleo isn't really happy with epel....

The UBI8 images repos are so small that we have to use the repos coming from the CentOS 8 host (see here l102 where we copy the repos dir to /opt/ and we share this dir to the images through the molecule.yml files). We actually don't need EPEL in validations-common because, today, no validations are using hiera or others exotic packages coming from it. The potential problem we could have if we don't do this now, is one day if a new validation is coming and needs something from EPEL, the developer won't be able to install the epel-release rpm from the molecule.yml file (pkg_extras list) because new repos will have to be enabled here before running the image. 

Here, I just replicated exactly what we have in tripleo-validations regarding the molecule tests CI infra.

And last, we activate epel for molecule tests only and don't install nothing for now! not harmful imho.

swift/cli/relinker.py.message:
so just want to confirm my understanding of the bug in question. At the time of required_links there wasn't a link becuase we know we needed to link the old loc file in the new location. But between then and now there must have been a race and a object from a different (oldler partpower increase part) has gone and made this link. So we're dealing with another race in essence?

My 2 questions are, and really to play devils advocate and just to clarify my thinking:

 1. Do we know how this happens? why an old part power location isn't cleaned up, or is it just something that was missed. As you say it seemed to only be .ts files.

 2. If something else is in the new location, cant we say it had to come from another relinker? I mean we're relnking to a file with a timestamp in the name right? So to get there between our get_ondisk_files and now means another relinker has already done the same check.. so if we get an EEXISTs here then it MUST be a copy of the file we're trying to link (right?)?

Just saying link exists on errno.EEXIST might suffice and means no more checking and IO.

Having said all that, this isn't inline on all requests or relinks and only double checks in the case of a race. So I'm fine when it's a better safe then sorry situation 😊

I wrote up the bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1921718 , including why the old partition power location was not cleaned up.

required_links does not imply they are missing, it just means 'these are the links that need to exist'. The problem arose when the link exists but to a different inode, then we logged an error, rightly IMO because this is unexpected.

With this patch we now expect the previously unexpected and try to establish if it is at least reasonable, given the known historic bug.
Is the first one necessary? Didn't we already try that one at L341?

this may be a tombstone in the older (previous) part power location, so the link that was previously attempted at l341 may not have been from part_power location to next_part_power location.

as noted below, I'm not too bothered about repeating the same link attempt in this uncommon case
Probably want that to be configurable.
agree, i wanted to see if the idea would fly before investing in plumbing config

I feel like we could base this off of prev_part_power (with a fallback, if that's not set, to part_power). If at some point we allow you to skip straight from 17 to 20 (say), there's no reason to check 18 & 19 -- you want to spend that I/O checking 15 & 16.

we need to include part_power as well as previous part powers because this may be the misplaced tombstone blocked by the correctly placed tombstone: we saw both current linked to next and prev failing as well as prev linked to next and current failing.
Ah, right, right...
This should always be false, yeah? The idea coming in here is that we've got a file at new_hash_path already -- is there are way that we'd be creating a new link given that?

certainly expected to be false, but might not be - things might have changed since we tried to make the link the first time e.g. new data has been PUT, existing tombstone has been deleted, so the link attempt here actually succeeds.
Could probably have this take new_file and drop the os.path.join'ing in check_existing.
good point
Nothing about existing_link?
Done
So existing_link comes from target_file, which has the filename... while hash_path doesn't -- shouldn't this be comparing existing_link and old_file?
good catch

I wonder if this should be at least info -- even if it's something we can recover from, it's not entirely "expected", right? If we're not running with --debug ('cause that's pretty noisy!) would it be worth making sure it still turns up in logs?
Yes, I was thinking the same - I'd like to see if this happens! I'll bump to info

Not

 unwanted_files.extend(old_df_data['files'])

?
old_df_data['files'] is a superset of required_links
s/3/several/
Cool -- I was going to make a comment about absolute vs relative paths on the previous patchset ;-)
it turned out that the absolute path also worked here due to os.path.join being "intelligent"...but for mere mortals using filename seemed a much better idea :)

test/unit/common/test_utils.py.message: We should maybe have that one throw a ValueError...

doc/source/admin/ovn/igmp.rst.message: Let me ask you: if igmp_snooping_enable=False (default), we should allow mcast traffic to all ports, this is the default behavior. Why this parameter is always false?

Yes, this will work (tested and talked with dumitru, the core OVN engineer that implemented the IGMP feature).

Basically if mcast_snoop=false (which is set accordingly to igmp_snooping_enable config) the mcast_flood_unregistered configuration will be ignored and the multicast traffic will be flooded.

So having it set to "false" always in this patch does two things:

1) It will be consistent with the current ML2/OVS behavior

2) It will make backport easier

To expand on 2), I believe we need a new configuration option for this behavior but that would make backports more complex (adding new config). So I decided to fix it like this first and later add a new configuration so people can tweak this behavior for their envs as they like.

What you think ?

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
One question, while creating a resource we subtract 1 from the old reservation and after that we're setting the new value here set in conf which doesn't account for the current resource creation, is this intended?
Suppose we initially set until_refresh value to 5, create volume (now value is 4) stop c-api service set it to 2, start c-api service, create a volume (here res_until is 3 then we set it to 2. should it be set to 2 or (until_refresh - 1) i.e. 1 ?

It doesn't really matter, but it should be set to 1, since in that case the resource until refresh is lower than the current value, which is the case we don't care about (we only care about the 3 cases mentioned in the comment).

The reason is that we want to have an until_refresh value in the resource that is consistent with the current configured value.

So we don't want those 3 cases:

- Resource value is disabled but config is enabled
- Resource value is enabled but config is disabled
- Resource has a greater value than the configured one
Thanks for the explanation. The code handles the mentioned cases.

Thanks for the explanation. Modified in PS5

The above code seems awkward, and judging by when the service_name gets discovered, only that and the remaining units will get notified.  This may be intentional, but seems a bit strange.

Rather than assume that the client application/service name is the same across all related units, why not actually verify that condition?  Then after that, update the data and then set it across all the client relations?

Or, find the first one that is advertising the name and then set it across all the units.
